Topic: Law
Context: A realtor will show a prospective buyer seven houses—J, K, L, M, N, 0, and P—during a single day. The first and second houses to be shown will be shown in the morning; the third, fourth, and fifth houses to be shown will be shown in the afternoon; the sixth and seventh houses to be shown will be shown in the evening. The houses will be shown according to the following rules: J must be shown in the evening. K cannot be shown in the morning. L must be shown at some time after K is shown and at some time before M is shown.
Question: Which one of the following is a pair of houses that CANNOT be shown consecutively in either order?
Choices:
  A: J, K
  B: J, M
  C: J, O
  D: J, P
  E: M, P
Reflection:
You previously answered this question incorrectly.
Then you reflected on the problem, your solution, and the correct answer.
Use your self-reflection (below) to help you answer this question.
Any information that you are not allowed to see will be marked [REDACTED].
Explanation:
I incorrectly chose C as the answer because I did not consider all of the rules. 
The correct answer is A because J must be shown in the evening, so it cannot be shown consecutively with any other house. 
Error Keywords:
 - Misinterpretation of rules
 - Overlooking rules
 - Incorrect reasoning
Solution:
J must be shown in the evening, so it cannot be shown consecutively with any other house. 
K cannot be shown in the morning, so it cannot be shown consecutively with any other house in the morning. 
L must be shown at some time after K is shown and at some time before M is shown, so it cannot be shown consecutively with K or M. 
O is not mentioned in any of the rules. 
Therefore, the pair of houses that cannot be shown consecutively in either order is J, K.
